post_text:
Hi to everyone!
Today I found plenty of those insects in the condo, most of them by the curtains. Finally i understand why i wake up in the night with big bites on my body and big swollen bubbles on my body.. that’s what is probably biting me over the night. They look like normal flies but they are not. 
Also, after trying to catch and kill many of them, despite they are like sleepy and easy to catch when in the curtain, when they wake up they are very aggressively attacking me. 
Hard to die even with Baygon..
Any idea what are those and what do I need to do? I will leave for ten days Phuket and my condo will be closed, maybe I need to spray something but what?
Thank you all for the help and info.

comments.comment: My guess is Tetragonula Laeviceps, a tropical stingless bee.

subcomments.subcomment: thank you very much Anthony. They definitely bite me, I wake up in the night bitten and have big “balls” on my body. Unless it’s something else that is biting me. And they are very aggressive too. Is it normal to be in the houses? I mean you see them often? Thank you very much once again
subsubcomments: Anonymous member They are quite common. Like with wasps and hornets if they start showing up there's a hive somewhere within a few hundred metres. They don't have the huge range of "regular" bees.Probably not inside your apartment if you only encounter like half a dozen of them. They don't really like cold either so I doubt they'd build inside if you have AC running (the cold is also probably why they seem sleepy).Most likely culprits are any old tree near or under your balcony or old outdoor garbage bins. They CAN build into wall and balcony crevices but they really prefer old half rotten wood and such.They're usually not too aggressive though unless they for whatever reason think you're threatening them or their nest. The bitemarks look like bad mosquito bites.

thank you for your time! Yes, i seen them outside my window today, but still many inside the room... always at the one window side, and most seem that die from the heat. I don't have much cold inside.

comments.comment: Looks somewhat like horse flies. Maybe some dead there that a fly will lit on and lay eggs. The maggots will become flies. Maybe

subcomments.subcomment: what shall I do? I can’t sleep all night, when I see one it’s attacking me. I was sitting in computer and vzziiin vzzziin near my eye and when I try to get them they disappear, or sometimes attack. Got plenty in the bedroom. What shall I do??
now that I look one it’s not like a horsefly at all. More like a normal fly and a bee..
subsubcomments: Anonymous member not horseflies. They are a small type of bee. They don't sting (much). I have not seen them aggressive, unless they get down inside your shirt while riding a bike and eventually they will sting you. Perhaps there is a nest or hive near your house and they are swarming/reproducing. Close your windows and doors for a few days?

is it possible they make the nest something inside the condo? Because always the windows are closed, I just opened once with but I have windows with flies protection grid. So or the eggs / small flown with the air to the curtain, or they have a nest inside the condo or probably over the roof?
it's possible. they try to make a nest inside any small cavity.

comments.comment: Look for pet control Co.

subcomments.subcomment: thank you

comments.comment: You should ask professionals about this.
Apis andreniformis maybe
They shall remain anonymous
Get the uv light machine, will kill them all easily..

subcomments.subcomment: which one??

Muffin needs a home!!!

The lady who offered him a home on 24th isn't answering my messages, so I've been hanging out all this time for nothing, it seems.

Requirements:

A large area
A fellow pig friend
A mud pit and pond/creek/tub
Shady area and sun
A covered sleeping place
Human interaction
Specially prepared meals in addition to pig feed,as he can't chew, so blended or finely chopped soft food

Muffin's story;

Muffin was taken by some people (probably kids) when he was 2 months old and 2kg. He was then brutally attacked with a machete, suffering 7 deep gashes to his face and legs. He lost an eye from the attack.

After a couple of months at the vets and several operations, he came to my home while I searched for a home for him. He's had two offers, but both have fallen through.

Muffin is sterilised, familiar with dogs and quite affectionate. He needs a forever home.

comments.comment: YES if you don't have a recent history of staying in Thailand during COVID-19 and afterwards...Safer to do a simple LAND BORDER BOUNCE out and re-enter Thailand same day. Gets you 30 days stamp on arrival as Visa Exempt Entry Plus one 30 day extension of stay at your local Thai Immigration office for 1900 Thai baht.Can do a maximum of 2 LAND BORDER BOUNCE entries into Thailand EACH CALENDAR YEAR plus one 30 day extension of stay at Thai immigration office each entry

post_text: Hi 👋 I was wondering if anyone knows where I can get e cigs? Are they really forbidden here or is that an exaggeration?

comments.comment: Ask in the bars. Yes they are illegal.
They are illegal here but plenty available for sale. Try any of the cannabis shops and ask in there.

subcomments.subcomment: technically, not illegal to possess. Only to import or sell. Chewit said a few months ago the police will not be levying anymore penalties for people possessing them as they should not have been doing that to begin with. Once the sandal with the Taiwanese actress happened, it was too public for them to get away with the bribery anymore.

comments.comment: Vendors on tourist streets, cannabis shops (not necessarily on display), sellers walking around bars and market areas, shopee or facebook.Yes they are illegal but there's basically a "don't bother tourists about them" policy in place after a few too many scandals where cops fleeced entire Chinese tour groups with crazy 50,000+ baht fines hit the international media.Remember the ones sold here are all knock offs (even when they appear to be in very official looking sealed boxes) that haven't gone through any safety checks, so don't leave one in the sun at a bar counter etc.

If you get caught with one by the police they will try and extort 30k off you as they are illegal as ridiculous as that is given weed is legal. Happened to my girlfriend recently and cost her 5k into the policeman's pocket to not have to go to the police station. Luckily she had some cash on her The chances of being checked are very slim and he saw it whilst she was getting her driving licence out on a traffic stop. Worst case in Thailand was a Dutch woman who was deported and cost her nearly 300k in fines, legal and a week in prison. That's the extreme but yes, there's loads of places selling them

subcomments.subcomment: Been vaping 8 years here, no problem whatsoever, just don't vape in public. many online sellers

post_text:
Season's greetings everyone. 

Sometime on Friday 29/12 our son's bike got taken from under our house in Soi Khokyang, Rawai. A real shame as, not only it being Christmas, we'd just started allowing him to ride to his friends houses on the back roads and he was enjoying his first taste of freedom! 

I don't think a professional thief as we had a load of power tools out which are worth a lot more than the bike but weren't touched. (Everything is locked away now..)

If you spot some youngster in the neighbourhood riding a newly acquired green and black Fortem bike, please could you drop me a message? I will be discreet about any info I get, thanks.

comments.comment: Sorry to hear that hope you will recover the bike in good condition.

post_text: What time does Makro in Patong close?

comments.comment: Did you google it?

subcomments.subcomment: Yes, but TIT, deviating info

comments.comment: 9pm.

subcomments.subcomment: Ok, thanks. I also found info about 10 pm but guess that is wrong
subsubcomments: All but 2 Makro's in all of Thailand close at 10pm so it's a common misconception

hmmm. So u have been to every Makro in thailand? Muah  I know of 3 Makro just in phuket that close at 9pm so that’s already one more than the two you mentioned in the whole of thailand. Hihi. PS - just saying. My reply is more meant to be amusing and TIT.

Nah, but I did check the official Makro Thailand homepage and it says (or apparently claims) that Patong and Koh Chang are the only exceptions. I only know 5 Makro´s on Phuket and from my experience they all except for Patong close at 10pm so from my experience I had no reason to think the official page would be lying to me.But hey, I live right next to the Patong one so at least the initial answer should be accurate if I´m not completely losing my mind!

absolutely you are not losing your mind  well not regarding this 555 This is why at best these groups are great. Because most things can be very ‘random’ here lol. I mean in many places in the world if one has a sign saying open 9-5 then one could be positive those are indeed opening and closing times as in many cultures that is very important. Here it can mean nothing even for quite big businesses. I smile (usually) when people refer to the clock here as ‘Thai time.’But I would be a liar even after 16 or so years of living here that it has not sometimes frustrated me. To turn up and a place of business should be absolutely open but it’s closed. Etc etc I love relaxed approach but I also believe heavily in being punctual. To many living here that won’t matter. And perhaps they are right.

comments.comment: 9pm

46 years old
Single
No dependants

I don't qualify for retirement VISA.

comments.comment: You have limited options. I would suggest you first get an ED visa, there’s a limited number of times you can extend it but it will give you the time to decide if you want to stay longer and the Elite visa is for you.

subsubcomments: absolutely... AVOID Volunteer and ED Visa if there's fraud involved...ie... NOT studying and NO Volunteer work done. They're HUGE PROBLEMS for those who have them in their passport

yes there are agents that promise these with no obligation but it's dodgy. Have to go through a legit school and attend classes (for ED). I think the volunteer (foundation) visas are prettyuch suspended now and anyone offering one is likely a fraud.
interesting...thank you.

subcomments.subcomment: thank you. That's what I'm considering. I've come and gone a few times now.. since arriving in March. I don't want to be denied, so I think it's time I figure out a solution:)

you should try to talk to an accountant or lawyer who could setup the company for you

subcomments.subcomment: thank you. I've done my 2 extensions for this year, and left a few times as well.
subsubcomments: Sorry, didn't know you were here already.

comments.comment: Elite Visa
Under 50, go for education visa, over 50 retirement visa.Find a local thai teaching school , almost all will look after the visa.I can chat aboout a few in Phuket that i know.

You mention you have enough money from your retired business. That’s a good start . If I were you I would definetely look into the Thai elite options, they have just been revised but for someone like you it should still be attractive, with 46 you can do the 5 year option and after that just apply for retirement visa. Advantage, you’ll be all set with bank account and all when time comes for the retirement visa, it will be a walk in the park coming from TE. Disadvantage, its a bit pricey.  My advice, stay far away from ED and volunteer visa’s. A lot burned their fingers on them later where they got denied extensions or re-entry.

Hello to all,
I am confused, could you please clarify ?
I am on business visa, I was in a trip out of Thailand and get back to Thailand, do I have to go to immigration after my arrival and report the address? I live at the same address i was living before I left for the trip (own condo). Do I need to go to immigration or no? Anonymous member no you have to update your Tm30 address registration. Your 90 days restarts the day you entered.

subcomments.subcomment: Thanks Not yet, I need a job letter to get the work permit.
subsubcomments: a job letter won't get you a work permit. Either you are offered a job and the company which is going to employ you applies for a work permit on your behalf on the basis that they have a minimum share capital of 2 million baht per foreign work permit, or you apply for a work permit after forming your own Thai limited company for which you also have to show registered capital of at least 2 million baht. On that basis you could then work for another company through your own company as a consultant. That's what I did for many years.
Thanks a million I really appreciate

post_text:
Друзья! 
Всём доброго дня! 
Предложение для тех, кто располагает торговыми площадями на острове, или только собирается открыть свой бизнес. 
Подобного нет на острове. 
Вы будете первыми и единственными. 
Продам вендинговые аппараты по изготовлению и продаже сувенирных жетонов из латуни с изображениями Тайланда. 
Забавный сувенир на память о проведённом времени. 
Чистая прибыль 1900℅.
Аппараты Российского производства. 
Не прихотливы в работе. 
Потребляют малое количество энергии ( 100 бат за месяц работы) 
Занимают четверть кв. метра площади. 
Работают самостоятельно без участия продавца ( нужно только время от времени заряжать латунные заготовки и инкассировать деньги) 
К каждому аппарату прилагается 5 000 заготовок. 
С учётом конечной стоимости жетона 100 бат, на выходе получается 500 000 бат. 
Аппараты уже на Пхукете. 
Их колличество ограничено.

post_text:
Hey All!  
Posting anonymous because I am pretty sure my LL is on here... 
Anyways, my landlord is an absolute D***.  He refuses to pay for any repairs and says everything should be out of our pocket because we are living there.  Example, our water pump has broken and he expects us to pay for the repair.  

Now I do agree with paying for aircon cleaning and keeping the house in nice condition, BUT the water pump?  That seems like it is home upkeep and should fall in the owners costs.  

Do foreign tenants have any rights or do we need to just suck it up.  

*moving is not an option, so looking for any advice or insight.  

Thank you all!

comments.comment: Call a local lawyer. Anything else is just hearsay. What does your lease say? Surely stuff like that is covered in the lease.

subcomments.subcomment: I guess this means he has to pay
subsubcomments: Anonymous member yes correct, however right and wrong on paper doesn't always translate to right and wrong in reality. The cost of you taking him to court far outweighs the issue plus any goodwill between you both is lost. He should repair it however is he chooses not to it may be more sensible for you to serve notice and move house

not necessarily. A letter of intent from a lawyer costs around 2,000 thb. That along with a copy of the lease agreement shiuld do the job. Flip side would be that the owner would likely be a pain in the a$$ when it comes round to getting the deposit back.

comments.comment: Personally, I would consider the rent level you pay because abroad this practice would of course not be acceptable
Check your lease, normally you are not liable for this unless it states so in the contract.

Contracts don't overwrite the law. They need to pay for wear and tear such as a pump. Offer to pay it and take it from the rent is what I've done in that situation and the landlord doesn't have a leg to stand on unless you broke something.

subcomments.subcomment: yes I agree this should be down to the landlord for sure. I would do the same getnit fixed and send the bill to the landlord and take from next month's rent

comments.comment: Unfortunately I got similar issues...now it's high season those s*** LL do not give a f*** as they know they will find someone else quickly to fill in
Thanks all! I'll let you know what happens. He had offered to pay 50%...

It all depends on the wording of your contract, generally speaking you are correct however sometimes places are rented out very cheaply and it's possible for the tenant to be responsible but it's not normal

subcomments.subcomment: this is the contract. I just hope we aren't shooting ourselves in the foot so he raises rent MORE! Paying 40k now, so it is hardly cheap.
subsubcomments: Anonymous member yes you are right but it's probably more about your relationship with the landlord. You can see that you are right but you have to judge the value of you being correct and holding him to the agreement Vs the problems that it can cause. Having a good landlord is far more valuable than any written contract. Maybe you could politely point out that he has an obligation to pay whilst at the same time point out things that you have done as a good tenant. It's a bit like a mirror you often get back what you are

I  agree.  I strive to be a good tenant.  Rarely reach out for anything. House is kept in good working order. Lawn kept nice. Try to fix any issues without involving him.  I don't think anything would change from his point of view. I think he is just money hungry and doesn't want to give up anything. I do wish we had a good relationship,  but ultimately I don't think he cares at all. Just looks for the rent each month.
Anonymous member it's often the way unfortunately
thanks for the info!

comments.comment: I normally agree a clause below 5k tenant avoids changing light bulbs etc above landlord pays

subcomments.subcomment: that is understandable and fair enough.

My name is Lucy 😇 I am a very kind girl.  I am 9 months old, I am vaccinated, sterilized and completely healthy.  I was born in the forest.  I had 3 brothers and one sister.  One brother found a family and he is happy.  The second one died under the wheels of a car 😢 The third one is now with me, on the street he survives among aggressive adult dogs who offend my brother and me.  He is also vaccinated and neutered and is completely healthy.  We really want to find families where we will be loved, where we will be safe and finally no one will bite us.  We love people and dogs, but some people and all dogs don’t like us 😢😢😢 help my brother and I find a loving family, every day we dream of our own home, where we will be, for the first time in 9 months, safe 🙏🙏🙏

post_text: Can someone refer me to the best remedial massage in Phuket? I’ve had shoulder issues for years and only the best therapists can help. Thanks in advance.

comments.comment: Yanee Duangdee is highly recommended for sports injuries … she may be able to assist

subcomments.subcomment: thank you!

subcomments.subcomment: thank you!
is there a specific therapist you’d recommend? Who’s the best there?
subsubcomments: Gray Timmons BB speaks good English and knows his stuff.

subcomments.subcomment: not sure I'd agree, but each to their own

comments.comment: Icare physio in kathu

subcomments.subcomment: thank you! I’ll try them out!

comments.comment: Hi Gary shoulder issue for years and massage? mmmm there are physiotherapists, myotherapists, remedial therapists, chiropractors, osteopaths, acupuncturists and more all working in that space. Shoulder yrs? You are talking rotator cuff tendinitis, bursitis, supraspinatus tendinitis (a variation of rot. cuff), adhesive capsulitis, potential labrum tears, and throw in if years possible osteophytes (calcium spurs) read degenerative arthritis to hoot. And factor in if not treated correctly with inappropriate massage techniques they can make many of the above much worse. Just a thought Gary sorry. Yes I am a therapist: Chiropractor, Osteopath Naturopath and also use dry needling acupuncture. Good luck Dr Ray

subcomments.subcomment: Ray Dixon thank you for your detailed response. I’ve recently had several chiropractic adjustments, dry needling, remedial massage therapists. It’s gotten better but I still have regular numbness in ky arm down to my hand. I injured my rotator cuff playing basketball and separated it in a dirt bike accident years ago. It’s mostly healed but I think there’s a lot of scar tissue. I also used to be an endurance athlete and did 200-300 pushups for years. There’s a lump in my upper scapular area and a few other painful spots around my shoulder have developed over the years. I found an excellent remedial massage therapist in Pattaya who worked in a hospital. She also did the best adjustments I’ve ever had. I’d never felt better and also found her via FB recommendation. I had some dry needling last week in Koh Samui. I’d like to check out your practice while I’m here.
subsubcomments: Boontavi at UK Massage Pattaya. She’s intense but she’s one of the best I’ve seen.

Then as predicted I got that part right. Radicular symptoms down your arm like that are not typically shoulder caused (possible but not as likely). Far more likely ostoephytes in the IVF of the cervical spine (lower neck) (compressing spinal nerve root exit points) or disc herniations. No ammount of massage would do anything for those if so. Anyway I PM you. Dr Ray

comments.comment: Here I am
Yanee Duangdee yes highly recommend for your shoulder issue

subcomments.subcomment: I already messaged her. Thank you.

comments.comment: Vachira Hospital and the most Health Center have medical massage. Medical Thai massage is a different education than recreational massage. The costs are similar.
Do Sauna soft oil massage one time your body unblocked by the heat of the steam, the more you hurt the more you push it will effect even worse.
Sleep with one pillow and a lady of the nightCheers
depending where you live, maybe see ... he doesnt do remedial massage, he sure as hell fixed my shoulder after years of problems from navy injuries that the "best" experts in Aus couldnt fix...
It doesn't need an operation.  Cheers

post_text: Im at the airport now, and just realizing my visa exempt says until October 16th… shouldn’t I have 30 days? If my math is correct, that’s only 29? Is this likely to cause me any issues when going through immigration or my status if I ever come back this year?

comments.comment: It's fine and common , don't worry about it

Been there, done that. There are two outcomes.  #1 if  the immigration officer is in a good mood, they'll let it slide and let you through.  #2 they'll make you pay 500thb.  There are no lasting consequences for a 1 day overstay.
30 Days it's correct
Don't confuse nights with days.  As in Accommodation for example.

subcomments.subcomment: yup I guess that’s what I did. Makes sense now.
yeah I guess I didn’t count my arrival as day 1, but it makes sense now.

comments.comment: All good ..
You need help with the visa ?
it’s from 00:00:00 on 17/09 to 23:59:59 on 16/10, that’s 30 days
Your math is not correct lol. That’s 30 days exactly friend
17th to the end of 16th is 30 days. It wont be a big issue
Immigration does not make mistakes.
If you count the days there are 30 days from 17 September to 16 October.  Both days are included.
Count from 17 to 30, including the 17th thats 14 and  + from the 1 to 16 = 30 days
In some cultures, when you are born you are one. When you are one year old, you are two
It’s correctDay 1 is always the stamped in day regardless of what time you arrive
its correct!
You just need to pay 500 baht for every day you overstay.

subcomments.subcomment: up to 20k, I over stayed for 6 years once and only paid 20k and like 2k to bribe the cop. Was back in a week...ahhh good times
subsubcomments: the laws have changed, you overstay now and you may not be welcome back.
yeah yeah, that's what they used to say before as well... The law was the same as now, as long there is corruption, you will be fine

comments.comment: The day you arrived its already counted.
The day of arrival is counted as the first day.
That's how they do it in Thailand.
Arrival Day Is Day 1

You have to have a Thai driver's license for five years before you can get an international driving permit issued here. But yes, get a Thai driver's license, you can't renew your foreign IDP here, only in your home country. But you don't need it, it's only valid for one year for a reason, they want you to get a local driver's license. Easy as... here.

you need to be in your country to renew it, best you could have done it get a Thai driving license using your IDP but now it’s probably too late (DLT takes more than a month for an appointment) unless you use an agent

comments.comment: As others have said, it depends what you're looking for. Phuket has turned into a shopper and diner paradise, with plenty of options for accommodation. Phang Nga is a big province. Most of it is farmland and small villages 99.9% occupied by Thai people. The only real tourist area up there is Khao Lak. Most of the people I know who live in Khao Lak run businesses. If you want to immerse yourself into village or city life with your neighbors being Thai, look at Phang Nga Town, Kok Kloi, the waterfall areas around Lampi. There are some nice golf courses in Phang Nga like Katathong. It's countryside, jungle, farmland, temples. If you move there you will have to learn to speak Thai if you don't already. There is no international hospital yet if that is a concern, there are no shopping malls except places like Tesco and they don't carry the range of products Phuket's stores do. The roads are great if you like to drive fast.

subcomments.subcomment: thanks! Good tips!
subsubcomments: Good luck.

comments.comment: Instead of

subcomments.subcomment: Phuket.

comments.comment: I think the answer is kinda obvious. Phuket is crowded, expensive and busy, but also includes great variety in terms of food, cafe's, malls, events, nightlife and people to meet. If you don't need any of that and are looking for a more relaxed environment, then Phang Nga would check most boxes. Personally, since I'm beyond partying/nightlife (which I did enjoy several years ago), I do find Phang Nga living an interesting idea, but I still appreciate the variety to be found across the island of Phuket. Maybe when I get closer to retirement. As stated by others, it depends on where you are at in life and what you are looking for.

subcomments.subcomment: yeah I guess I don’t mind somewhere quieter at retirement but would probably drive down to Phuket once in a while for the good restaurants and massage.

For sure

Hi,

We are a family of 4 from Norway visiting Nai Harn/Chelong and Lighthouse Int. school and kindergarten for the next 2-4 months.

G'day all. Hey, can anyone recommend a bookkeeper on the island who can:

comments.comment: Express is the common accounting software in Phuket. QuickBooks have also a Thai version, this was done together with NAT accounting. They have also a branch in Phuket. For Express you get support direct from Express. If you don't like to connect the internal accounting with the accounting for the Revenue Department, than look for a remote freelancer to setup it.Another good program is Flowchart, it delivers a good amount of reports including charts. Easy to use, but the most accountants in Phuket don't use it.I use internal Flowchart and my Accountant use Express. My internal accounting is used to check the external and write invoices/ quotations.External I use Tacteam, they are good (the owner is auditor). But work only with Express. I know some companies that use NAT Accounting, they are also happy, they are well known for international standards.

post_text:
Hey all - anyone here in the motorbike rental business? Or interested in making some extra money with their motorbikes? 

Working on something - would love to connect. Cheers.

comments.comment: Only afraid someone would crash it, damage it or worse - steal my bike though, how can you protect or provide insurance for that for me if I gave you one or 2 of my bikes?

subcomments.subcomment: We cover that in a few different ways:1) You can set a deposit, any damage you submit a claim and we grant you the deposit if everything is honest. 2) All renters undergo an ID verification with passport, Selfie, etc. So they can be tracked down - Phuket Airport immigration on speed dial. 3) They sign a contract at checkout. Contract squarely puts liability on them for damage they cause and grants right to do merchant initiated transaction to credit card. Nothing is without risk - but this risk is assumed by thousands of rental shops in Phuket everyday. Plus - Skoot as a company has your back, local to Patong/Phuket. If it doesn’t keep you safe, it doesn’t keep us safe either.
subsubcomments: sounds fair, what about the legality of renting my bike to other foreigners though, how do I not get in trouble for doing this.. or is that allowed ? Sounds like I'm making money without a business registration- how does that side of legal things work ?

It’s not against the law to rent your motorbike. Thousands of businesses rent bikes everyday - whether it’s their main business, or on an individual basis or side gig. Skoot is a registered Thai company, so there is a layer of protection there. I think the govt mostly cares about:1) Tax Revenue 2) Company registration if sufficient size. You can think of it as though you’re renting a bike on Facebook marketplace - but using a specialized app instead.
will B all renters be required to have a motorbike license ?
It is incumbent on all partners/shops to check for current drivers license. Skoot handles identity verification as a platform, licenses are handled by the shop. Safety and legality is our #1 concern.

comments.comment: Good idea. Let me know if you need some help on the business etc side of things.

subcomments.subcomment: Thanks mate!  Sure, always looking to connect with strong people. What’s your skill set?
subsubcomments: I own a-i-c.org but some of my personal background is also in business management and consultancy.
Very cool, I’ll check out your site.

Hi Everyone!  

I hope this message finds you well. I am reaching out on behalf of HeadStart International School to invite food vendors to participate in our second annual Aqua Panthers Swim Invitational. The event will take place on November 11th and 12th at our school campus.

We are expecting a significant turnout, with approximately 250-300 athletes, parents, and coaches attending the event. This means there will be a good amount of foot traffic, providing an excellent opportunity for vendors to showcase their culinary offerings.

The rate for participating as a food vendor is 350 baht per day. However, we kindly request vendors to commit to both days of the event to ensure a consistent presence throughout. 

To avoid any conflicts with our existing vendors, we kindly ask that you provide us with information about the type of food you sell. This will help us ensure a diverse and complementary range of food options for our attendees.

If you are interested in joining us as a food vendor for the Aqua Panthers Swim Invitational, please send me a private message. Feel free to include any additional details or questions you may have.

Thank you for considering this opportunity, and we look forward to hearing from you soon. Have a fantastic day!

subcomments.subcomment: HOMA was extremely accessible, we were really happy seeing it.
subsubcomments: great I will add them to the Accessible Phuket page, do they have a swimming pool lift?
if you could send me some pictures and a small review of the hotel that would be great info@disabledsailingthailand.org

I only took 2-3 photos that were of my interest in relation to a family memebers stay 2 are above in this post and the 3rd one was of the bathroom. Small review:The entrance had a nice ramp to go up from the front parking lot, but what I loved about this place was simply it was ginormous, the entrance was basically "outside" with a round desk in the middle, enough space everywhere, and the handicap rooms were on the ground floor really ease of access through a wide double door, the access to elevator and the yard had a nice walkway that is not "narrow and precise" but wide enough you can really enjoy rolling through it on a chair, the B7 floor where the dining area is, again nothing but wide spaces double doors and everything well thought out even the Gym area is wide open space so its easy to roll around and pickup weights, I was in awe.. The only drawback was that for some reason they failed to do a ramp to the swimming pool area, maybe an assumption that people in wheel chairs don't like to go sit in the shallow end and soak in the sun, it's about 4-5 steps up to a fake grass platform towards the pool, If you are with a family member this can be accomplished by simply helping one up stairs but it would be nice if it were cleanly accessible without assistance as sometimes pride can get in the way. With that said, we were really thrilled with the area (for our use as the family member isn't much a swimmer so maybe not a deal breaker for some, I personally myself am not a pool addict and have lived in the past in a condo 2 years entering pool 1, to each their own). it can really allow the induvidual to roam around his wide space room from bed to the toilet, to the chair in the shower, no steps or anything just flat surface nice area for anyone to transition from his chair to his shower chair, reminded you of a hospital WC stall spacious.We will definitely give it a go when the person comes down here

Regarding the swimming pool lift, unfortunately we checked all around found nothing, asked the desk and it turns out this is the only drawback, they are missing a ramp to this area.. the ONLY area the top roof swimming pool or they would have gotten 10/10 instead of 9/10 in my head. I saw so many nice shallow ends to sit down in and soak in the sun that I figured it would be accessible somewhere on the side but nothing, so no pool lift either since this area lacks. Again takes 1-2 points off in my book but the friendlyness and everything else being very accessible you could play basketball in the lobby with chairs, I gave it a thumbs up for the member.
Look at the lobby size

Unfortuantely this is where they missed the mark, access to this area, even shallow ends, anyway It's what we needed and I am glad I got this recommendation because of access we need in Phuket, we live in Phuket but the person coming, we want them to feel welcomed, so we can go about the day and do as little of "oh we can't go here, they don't accommodate wheelchair people" it's very big of a mood killer on a good day out .. Well that is all

comments.comment: Accessible Phuket page for more info

We found this husky running like crazy in the middle of the highway in Chalong almost getting hit by cars. It was starved, hair falling out and clumping, and very afraid of people. We took it to the vet, no issues or diseases after general checkup. We also washed it with shampoo and brushed out a lot of hair and blow dry until the fur was fresh again, as well as fed it good food. However even after all that we felt itchy to touch the dog and so we will treat it with anti fleas medicine in a few days as required by the prescription.

If you are the owner / know the owner / would like to adopt this husky please text via Line App, QR attached.

Does anyone know what is the status of PayPal business in Thailand? I know there were issues (closed) for a while, but now they say they are open for business accounts with proper registration. Yet when I submitted all the information for our restaurant and guesthouse, we were denied with no explanation except that our account has been restricted. 

What's the deal, anyone know?

subsubcomments: Wise got also strange with Co. Ltd. Accounts. They keept payments from customers without to inform me, don't even let me close the account.
oh? Maybe I just need to try it without the Co Ltd?

private account will be more easy I guess. And the most tourists don't really mind. But I would not anymore let a bigger amount at this accounts. Because when the trouble starts, they block your access.About Wise is a group in Facebook that exchange experiences about this. Wise is even so nice to tell you, that they don't close your account, because they are a service company

post_text:
Hello to all,
I bought a condo in patong (huge mistake to admit), which is freehold foreign. Between the many surprises, problems issues etc that make spend a lot, I realize that the power is NOT provided by PEA but I have to pay to the Juristic.
The juristic is charging 7THB per power unit instead of 5.2 that PEA does.
I will go tomorrow to PEA to see what I can do but as I understand there is no direct meter/power supply.
My question 🙋‍♂️is if anyone has faced the same and what is the suggested action, if any.
Yes, don’t tell me I should look better, I should had to do so, but now what?
Is it legal? I’m not renting, it’s my own condo.
Thank you all

comments.comment: To clarify, this building is a 5 star hotel that they also sell some of the rooms / condos. I have title deed and blue book.
To clarify, this building is a 5 star hotel that they also sell some of the rooms / condos. I have title deed and blue book.
Pretty sure this is wrong, I've a free hold condo in Phuket and only charged the PEA rate for past 10 plus years.

subcomments.subcomment: the juristic is charging this and they provide the supply. They told me that’s agreed and can’t changed. They charge 7THB per unit. Also told me I’m not allowed to install my own Pea
subsubcomments: Anonymous member and they can do that legally too. You could challenge this at a general meeting in the juristic, but then you need to have the votes (majority) to make it happen - which is unlikely if it is a hotel that just sell a few condos. I am pretty sure the maintenance costs are astronomical too. And that too is allowed

comments.comment: Pay and don’t worry. Many condos charge much more.

subcomments.subcomment: nah come on man
that wasnt the question
subsubcomments: I don’t reply anymore to cheap Charlie’s. This is the common way in Thailand in almost all the condominiums. The electricity company usually do not install separate meters in hundreds of apartments. I live in Thailand for more than 30 years. Due diligence before buying and no complaints later.
if that was your answer his question, you shouldnt have responded. It was a pointless response
you should mind your own business if I respond or not it’s my business.
sure you’re right! How you can find all those things
sure. I was merely pointing out your inability to read his question
I understood very well the question and gave my advice to pay and not complain because this is the way in Thailand.

gents thanks both! Peace please  David I totally agree with your approach “this is the way in Thailand” true.. hard but true    thank you!! I indeed get shocked with this insane overhead. And it’s my fault because it’s not first time I buy condo AND get actually scammed with many other issues that I’m still finding in it and need to spend a fortune to fix.

comments.comment: Some condominiums do charge extra for electricity. This is very common and it is in your contracts.The PEA won't interfere.You have a meter they read but are not setup for individual billing.The condo Juristic person is the managing entity of your building. Our building charges PEA rate but it is disclosed that a portion of our cam fees cover common area utilities. If it is a condotel then they are a for profit business, so will markup everything.

subcomments.subcomment: yea it’s a condotel and I bought one condo there. Owner, freehold. So why can’t I have my own pea? Isn’t illegal to charge 7 THB per unit?
subsubcomments: Anonymous member somewhere there is a law about it

Anonymous member no not illegal at all.Your condominium board/juristic person and they pay PEA.Then they mark it up at their discretion and settle rates.The PEA will not setup a single unit for individual payment.Just not how it's done.Your condominium will have transformers and electrical infrastructure that the building owns and maintains.It's just in the details that get missed when buying.Your  freehold ownership entitles you to a very small percentage of ownership in the property entity.We have a condo board that controls the Juristic person on behalf of the owners. The condotel may not have such a structure that is owner friendly.
Anonymous member no. Not illegal. It is buyer beware in Thailand. And it is in the paperwork

comments.comment: When you say there is no direct power supply do you mean you have no access to a meter for your condo?

subcomments.subcomment: Kathryn Ann Ridley they provide the power through the juristic office and they overcharge 35%. They ask 7 THB per unit instead of 5.2 of PEA
subsubcomments: Anonymous member unfortunately, this is common practice.  Surely, you must have known this before signing on the dotted line

subcomments.subcomment: Kathryn Ann Ridley they say that 7THB is agreed in the AGM meeting (before I bought it)
Kathryn Ann Ridley they say that 7THB is agreed in the AGM meeting (before I bought it)
subsubcomments: Anonymous member exactly. So at next AGM you can propose it is lowered. If there is majority for that, then it will be. If not, even if it is raised there, you cannot do anything. Welcome to "comunity life"
terrible situation

comments.comment: In this kind of set up the electricity meters for each condo will be privately owned by the juristic body.The PEA will have one electricity meter supplying the whole building and I expect the electric is going through a transformer which also will be privately owned by the juristic body. These transformers are very expensive to buy and also expensive to maintain as like ours they blow up quite often. The extra cost your being charged per unit goes towards maintaining the transformer and other associated infrastructure with a common electricity supply. In a case like this you can not arrange your own electricity supply directly with the PEA. If that rate of 7 thb per unit as been voted on and agreed at the AGM there is nothing you can do about it except pay. If you dont pay the juristic body will legally disconnect your electricity supply.

subcomments.subcomment: so I’m locked in this illegal thing. Pea told me on phone it’s illegal
subsubcomments: Anonymous member The PEA are incorrect , they have probably misunderstood you and think you are being overcharged through one of there meters. If the meters are privately owned by the juristic body then its completely legal.
you believe so? Are you aware of similar cases or just assuming ?

Anonymous member This is absolutely legal and common practice. Even if you do not like this responses to your question this is how it is done in Thailand. People that advise you to take legal action etc. are simply not aware of the situation.
Juergen Kohnen thank you  but why even pea told me to go apply

Anonymous member I think PEA probably misunderstood you when you talked to them. There are some housing developments and possibly even some Condo Complexes that have a meter for each house or room and PEA just send the Bill to you resp. Juristic Person and they give it to you. And you pay the official rate to PEA directly. But most common, esp. in Condos they charge you a higher rate. Should be mentioned in your purchase contract with them.
Juergen Kohnen I bought second hand from another person.. nowhere mentioned

comments.comment: A Condotel will probably work differently from a Condo, as they will rip the tourists off with the electrical charge. My  Condo has electrical meters for each unit, and I receive a bill every month from the PEA I rejected a higher charge in my rental contract. Normally the electrical meters are all together in an electrical room. See if you can find a room like that. As an owner living in the unit, you should be able to use the PEA bill  This is a very common scam

subcomments.subcomment: they don't allow any PEA installation etc. I spoke with PEA they told me that it's illegal but I can't do anything ,I have to talk with the juristic. They also stated that this is a fee agreed in the AGM meeting; I wonder why the owners would accept this. Last, I made some great friends / owners there, i seen they get around 8K charge of power per month.. insane.. i don't know what to do
subsubcomments: Anonymous member They agree on that amount because they rent the units out . If you accepted that amount in your sales agreement, you are basically screwed   Rent it out and buy another place . Or sell it on.. Electrical charge will be ridiculous , unless you only use the aircon's fan mode. They have big fights here, because Thai rules for Condo is minimum 30 days rental . The owners want to rent out to tourists during high season . So you get lot's of childish door slaming from the owners . I been here 5 years.Condotel is different, I assume.

Anonymous member the normal rate and this is what I pay on a standalone house connected directly to a PEA meter is 4.5 baht per unit, but a few days ago the new government have just reduced this to 4.1 effective on next month's bill.
in the sales agreement it says nothing. I bought it from other seller

comments.comment: All quite normal and perfectly legal , if your an  owner and your name is on the title and your not being billed directly by the PEA then the electricity supply to your unit is privately owned by the juristic person. There is nothing you can do about it , a lot of buildings in Patong are set up this way from the beginning.I agree with what others have said that the PEA have misunderstood the situation if they told you its illegal.
Nothing you can do. Unless you get everybody else to want to change and then it has to be voted in a GM meeting. Check the Rules and regulations book as to when that next meeting is.Good luck!

subcomments.subcomment: so you’re sure I can’t request legally my own pea supply?
subsubcomments: Anonymous member I was Juristic person before there are rules and regulations that owners must follow. To change those rules you must get a majority of owners to want to do that too. You would have to introduce a that idea and then it would need voting.You as an owner are bond by the R&R of the condo. That over charge should go back into the budget and used to up keep the pipes going to each unit and the meters. Check where those ver charge funds go after collection. Where do you find that in the monthly financial sheets.
thank you very much. My lawyer in bkk insists to sue them etc but I don’t want to get into this thing at all
Anonymous member long process.

comments.comment: Solar Energie is the Way i have build my own Electric in my house in Phuket.10 kw per day.The Instalation i have build by myselfself,all together 100000 Baht!

subcomments.subcomment: it will  take you how many years to recover the investment?

post_text:
Hello to everyone. Is there any clear understanding about the new tax rules? I read this today, which also means that the whole (existing) wealth will be taxed 🤣😂🤣. 
I’d appreciate it if one has more info to share here, I’m sure a lot are worrying of what is coming. 
I understand that any income brought to Thailand for any year will be taxed as income.
But what about income that is earned abroad and will not come to Thailand at all? Are there any clarifications?
I understand that there are many that are considering moving out in such case and might be already looking for alternatives. I’d appreciate learning options too.
My personal approach is that in such case, a lot of wealthy individuals will move out and that will end up as a loss for the country that we all love. 
Please share any info you might be having. Thank you.

Hi everyone,

I'm looking for information and references about the changes in the education visa process- specifically for those who have previously had a non-immigrant B visa and were employed at some point in Thailand.

I inquired on behalf of someone else at my language school and was informed that anyone with four stamps including tourist 30 day extensions or a Non-Immigrant B visa in their passport is no longer eligible for an Ed-Visa in Phuket. This rule apparently applies to all of Southern Thailand provinces. To obtain this visa, one must get a new passport entirely.

I've contacted a few schools and one mentioned getting a 12 month university education visa that actually includes a 90 day stamp (15 months total) but all of the paperwork would require a trip to Chiang Mai. Classes are done on Zoom. It's significantly more expensive and I'm a little concerned about the legitimacy of this visa as it ALSO requires a new passport after using it. 

Has anyone else run into this issue? Has anyone studied at a school elsewhere in Thailand and participated in online classes? Looking forward to your responses. Thank you!

comments.comment: Thai Immigration will love you when they see this Ed Visa

subcomments.subcomment: Thai Immigration will love you when they see this Ed Visa

comments.comment: New passports makes no difference whatsoever. They have your details already.
I just got a new passport, the 1st three pages are taken up with all the in and out dates from my previous one. Getting a new passport makes no difference to Getting a visa.

We’re currently in this process via local visa agents - our first edu visa was rejected due to this apparent new rule.They’ve assured us if we get new passports (which were, of course, completely fine and didn’t need renewed & had no more stamps than was allowed - we followed all the visa agents guidelines and advice perfectly) that we can then reapply and will - according to them, almost definitely get it approved  It’s wild and doesn’t make much sense at all… and of course has cost a fair amount of extra $. Will update here when we’ve got the outcome but apparently they ‘don’t check the system they just care about the stamps in your passport’

post_text: Okay, let me just throw in an observation.  A recent poster to this forum said, "there is a massive real estate scam in Phuket / Patong at the moment."  It's that "at the moment" that really caught my eye.  There is an absolutely marvelous book called "Siam Was Our Home," by Edna Brunner Bulkley.  She, with her doctor husband, established the first Western hospital in South Thailand in 1904.  She bore and raised six children there, and today there are still a number of Thai citizens named "Bulkley."  One was a granddaughter, who posted in 2004 that she had been selling real estate on Koh Samui but she was quitting because of all the chicanery, thievery, and dishonesty in the island's real estate industry.  So here's a woman with literally a century of Thai history behind her, a Thai citizen fluent in Thai with all the legal rights of a Thai citizen, but she's quitting her job because of the dishonesty she encounters every day.  I don't know why any farang coming to Phuket would think it would be any different there.  Come on, people.  You see all those condos on the hillsides?  They were all built with money scammed from people just like you.  Just like Vegas was built on the backs of the losers, so too any island's real estate industry.  Don't act surprised when the scorpion stings you on the far side of the river.  You knew what he was when you invited him to climb on your back.

comments.comment: Thx for the read!

Minimise risk =  buy on the resale market with a property older than 3 years.   You see what you are getting and how well it is being managed/maintained etc and better land office transparency available.
This post assumes way too much and seeks to make something that is not absolute as such. There are lots of foreigners who have villas without scams involved.

subcomments.subcomment: I don't deny it.  But there are more foreigners, and more local citizens, who lose money in real estate on Phuket than you would find in other places with similar properties.  Waaaaaaay more.  And there always have been.
subsubcomments: do you have anu proof of what you say? I am an investor since 30 years in Thailand and never had any problems in buying properties, even under a company name. Do your due diligence work and relax. i hate to listen to people speaking only negatively about Thailand.

post_text: Income from overseas will be taxable in the tax year you bring it in from January 1, 2024.

comments.comment: what's been changed?

subcomments.subcomment: Income from overseas that was brought in a different tax wasn’t subject to income tax in Thailand. After January 1, 2024, overseas income in the year that you have tax residency in Thailand is subject to income tax in the tax year that it is brought in.
subsubcomments: If I get it right, there was no taxation before until the income is brought to Thailand. So now have to pay anyway?
Before it was only taxed when tax residents brought the income in the same tax year the income occurred.

comments.comment: What about double taxation treaty? Thailand has this with at least 60 countries. If income is taxed in one country, it is not in the other in these cases.

subcomments.subcomment: Correct. If you fall into definitions of tax residency of more than one country, you look into the Double Taxation Agreement between countries to resolve the issue.

comments.comment: Nothing is changed. This is a directive to report overseas income based on laws that already are in existence. You underlined the words for any tax year, but you left out the important words of “assessable income”. It’s only assessable if it was earned in the current tax year.

subcomments.subcomment: The interpretation is changed that your assessable income you earn overseas in the year you are Thai tax residency will be subject to income tax whenever you bring it into Thailand. The existing law used to be interpreted that you don’t need to report when you bring in the income in a different tax year.

subcomments.subcomment: How much is appropriate
subsubcomments: I don't have the figure yet, my landlord is handling this part, right now they just closed the hole while its raining like crazy, then when they can get to it they will come here to break down few things to do this, It's probably gonna be a bit higher than that.Think of it like this, an aircon maintenance where they flush it out, etc, on a stepladder runs you 500 baht. That is something that takes maybe 15-25 minutes.This they need to repair the wall, perhaps dig deeper to resolve the water damage inside, they need to also come inside (at least here to repair the ceiling), this is going to cost much more than that.. longer hours, much more work.. I can't tell you honestly the price but I would just remove the 2000 baht out of the question and just get a quote  that way you will get PM/Line messages from people willing to do the work if you can come to an agreement of a price.. Don't mention a ceiling to your price, just PM and see if you can find someone willing to do the work and for how much.Good luck

Also one thing, it's also really good in these groups to just ask for recommendations, many people will give you good recommendations, numbers, lines, sites they use but saying "I can do 2000" limits you to non-professional work done and no one wants to suggest their friend who does this for a living knowing the 2000 sticker, just my two cents  hope you get yours fixed..PS: My Landlord gave me the price estimation for the fix she needs to pay out of pocket to fix this thing on the house.. It's not exceeding 10.000 baht probably she said fixing outside and the ceiling inside, but she also uses them often and recommends them and has a good deal with them.. So yeah the way she speaks indicates this kind of work runs you 10k or there about.. closer to 10k than 2k

comments.comment: Nitipong Law
Where are you located?
Nitipong Law can help you.
Usually accountants do this for you, not lawyers.
DM me.  Facebook won’t allow me to post details of the law firm I use (advertising).  They specialise in this

Good luck with that. You have a spouse visa, so that's a good start.Here are the next steps in order:1. Get a job.2. Get the employer to supply you with half a ton of paperwork to support your work permit application.3. Apply for work permit.You can't get a work permit and then look for a job. Only the other way around.Alternatively, you could set up your own company or partnership - it's not too difficult - but you'll need at least one Thai partner. Your wife? She'll need to be the senior partner so she can employ you.And you'll need to pay an accountant to keep the books in order and work out how much tax you personally and your company will have to pay.Your work permit will specify very precisely what your job is and the name of the company you work for.You may not do any other work or work for anyone else.The fact that you are asking this question suggests you want to work legally.I speak from experience. It's complex but doable without any input from a lawyer. You'll just spend many hours in govt offices. You will never have all the right documents first time round.But one thing you will NOT need is a lawyer. Just a good accountant.

subcomments.subcomment: thanksI have all of this just looking for the law/accounting firm to do itMy lawyer doesn’t do this
subsubcomments: Alexandre Boutemy Get an accountant.

accountant is better as WP requires all the paperwork, accounts, audited annual reports, tax returns, payslips etc from the company where you will work... And the lawyer would need to request this from, you guessed it. The accountant doing the company paperwork.

post_text:
Over the years we see hundreds if not thousands of posts on social media asking how much money do you need to live in Thailand. There are many different options of course, but the realistic answer in my opinion is each individual should "allow" the same amount per month that they spend in their home country.
(Although they may not spend that much)
A person that spends money on drink wild women and luxury in his home country will want the same thing in Thailand,while the person on a more modest lifestyle in the West will be more easily pleased.
Although different places in Thailand cost different in accommodation basically its not that much different between destinations for cost of living.
Phuket may cost 500-1000 baht more per day than say Pattaya for example but if someone cant afford that much price difference should they be moving to Thailand in the first place?

comments.comment: thats crazy!!! Thailand is much cheaper to live than the usa and most euopean countries  one could get by in the states on $4,000/month, while here u'd live like a king on that amount

subcomments.subcomment: some may think that but 140,000 baht isnt hard to spend each month 4,500 baht per day.AccomodationsFoodElectricPhoneDrinksInsuranceTransportation (Motorbike or taxi)Plus either girls or if someone has a thai wife they cost money.Also remember emergency money in case a problem occurs.Like i said they might not spend it but they should allow for it.

comments.comment: It’s not all about money. To get a visa might be most important. Anyway 500-1000 Bath per day besides rental payments is ok…

500-1000thb more per day in Phuket? Something's wrong with that math.My monthly expenses living here are around 30-40k THB and that's including eating out 2-3 times a day, gym, condo, and motorbike. I'm definitely not trying to live on a budget or anything like that either (I make 3x what I spend).

subcomments.subcomment: 40k per month for the basics maybe.What about entertainment,drinks girls or girlfriend, medical insurance,clothes,holidays and treats plus backup and emergency money?We all know shit can happen in a heartbeat in Thailand and although you may never need that much money you should have it just in case.Wouldn't you agree?
subsubcomments: I go to a bar maybe twice a month, I do have a Thai girlfriend (who I sometimes take to places like Phi Phi), and I do wear clothes. All covered in that. If you go around buying ladydrinks every other day sure you can spend 100k in a week but that's more being a tourist than an expat.If what you're saying is that one should make more money than one spends and have savings, that's just basic adulting and not exclusive to Thailand.

post_text: Does anyone use an agent for their 1 year extension based on Marriage? I am not asking for anything illegal or unethical, I have the required money in the Thai bank and I am married with kids and been in the country for 17 years. Im asking because im a very busy person who is always working and I have very young kids with me all the time, and doing this immigration stuff after soo many years has become a major drain on my time. I have to set aside a few days from work to do all the chores and gathering all the paperwork, and not working these days costs money. It seems it would be cheaper to pay someone to do most of this for me so I can maintain my schedule. Ideally id like to print all the needed documents for the agent and have them pick everything up from my house and do all the legwork at immigration and just call me and tell me when to be at immigration so that it doesnt take up so much of my time, and I can avoid all the run-around. If anyone does this, can you share how much you pay for the service, and what exactly they require of you? Maybe you can send me your agent details? Time is money and immigration is a huge hassle especially trying to haul my kids around with me.

comments.comment: Tmt visa
TMT Visa Service

If you have all required documents it will take you a couple of hours of your time to present them at immigration at Phuket town and collect them next day. Any company will charge you at least 10.000 Baht. I did it for 15 years in Phuket

subcomments.subcomment: Yeah, the total time invested is much more than a couple hours and double it if I have the bad luck of getting an unpleasant immigration guy who decides to give me the run around. My time is valuable to me and I’m trying to avoid as much interaction with the process as possible.
subsubcomments: well your choice. I am a 30 years resident of Thailand and just renewed my retirement visa last week in Pattaya. It took me no more than 15 minutes to present all right documents and 5 minutes to collect the passport with visa the next day. My long time lawyer asked me 10.000 to do it.  No thanks!

Pattaya (and everywhere else I’ve done this) must be different because it takes much longer than 20 minutes. What people fail to understand is that a days work for me is much more valuable and profitable than 10k baht. If I would have known 10 years ago I’d still be here I would have gotten Thailand elite and had none of these issues, but things creep up. If I take time from work it’s going to be for something I purely enjoy and going to immigration is one of the last things I’d ever want to do in my free time.
I was busy as you until 5 years ago when I sold my restaurants and hotel. Now am a free man!!
you must be the luckiest farang in Thailand. It never usually is so smooth for most people. That's why many are prepared to pay the agent for a hassle free experience.

comments.comment: Transfer fee: 2% of registered valueStamp duty 0.5% of registered valueWithholding tax: 1% of the registered or the appraisal value, the one that is the higher.There might be a specific business tax if the property hasn’t been registered for more than 5 years. comments.comment: How long is a piece of string? Need more info bud.

The Living Costs  are not the issue as all Budgets can be suited , Visa status is more important  ,  but I would suggest £1800 pm to live comfortably  , can be done on less though depending  on your choices .

Depends how you want to live you can live here cheaply eat street food and 7 11. A decent condo can be had for 30 -50000 a month add bills phone Internet water electric 3000. Google 2 bed condos plenty about. I think you be better renting a house though, can get a decent 2 bed house for 20k a month.  Motorbike rent 3000 a month. I can go out with the wife and daughter have 5 big beers plenty of food and have change out of a 1000. I can slso go out on my own with 5000 and wake up next day with 20 baht in my pocket, totally depends how you live can be done on the cheap if you can get out of holiday mode.

I would agree with all these comments, you can  live in a Thai House 20k or less a mth, live in high end condo can be 100k a mth or more. Thai food 60 thb a dish, Western restaurant can be 1000thb for a steak. Beer is different prices depending where you go, but gyms are cheap 2k thb a mth, petrol is cheap 37thb a litre, but then if you go out down Bangla Road for a night out that is 10k gone in a night easy

I own my house and truck, no finance, don't eat out, would not touch street food {i am a good cook}. Wine is my biggest outlay. Live quite well on around 1,000gbp a month, add another couple of thousand a year for medical insurance (1,500}, car insurance/tax (500} add in another 1,000 for minor house repairs so in total around 15,000 a year.

My house, 2 bedroom, 2 bath 15,000b a month.  My neighbor, 2 bedroom, one bath, 13,000b￼ a month.  Free water, free cable TV, free wifi, electric less than 2000b a month.  Love street food.  It’s cheap!
Thanks everyone, this is a really helpful guide, I was seeing if I could live on £1500-2000 a month ideally so seems possible?

subcomments.subcomment: Easily. After the "honeymoon phase" all my monthly expenses averaged to around 1000-1500€ a month. I live in a touristy town too, so if I moved to say Kathu or Phuket Town I could probably get another 2-300€ off that. Just make sure you live close enough to a Makro, Lotus, Supercheap, or a fresh market (normal Thai grocery shopping, so you don't just shop at 711. That really adds up more than you'd think during a month).
for sure you can, quite comfortably too!

comments.comment: https://www.numbeo.com/cost-of-living/in/Phuket

I would budget 100,000 THB per month (2 persons)House/ Apartment 35kUtilities 3kHealth Insurance 10kCar insurance 1.5kVisa costs 3kDining out 18kGroceries 15kGym/ massage/ activities 5kGym 3.5kTravel/ Gasoline 5kIn 6 months time, this could be well around 80k

You can get a pretty decent small condo (30sqm) for maybe 8000-10000thb with pool and gym, bike rental 4000thb etc so you can easily have a decent life without wanting for much for £1000 a month and that includes eating out every night etc

I would say between £1000 and £2000 as a basic range. You could do cheaper on the bottom range but not comfortably, Currency rates will vary and bear in mind depending on the kind of visa you get there may be a minimum income requirement. Phuket is not an especially cheap place to live and if you are watching the pennies you might be better of in Pattaya or even up north.

It must just be me, a 2 bed condo or house can range from £350 per month to anything, utility bills from £30 per month to again upwards, you'll need transport strangely second hand vehicle can range from ok to high, visa is important if over 50 you can get a retirement visa in easy terms, if you can eat in & cook all depends on you preference, if you drink out you can hunt bars that sell cheaper drinks, i own my own properties, cars, motorcycles, scooters, etc, so cheap per year to pay for properties, vehicle tax insurance, hunt health insurance out, i eat in as trained in cooking, when out yes drink but cheap enough, so literally well below £10k, id say £6k to £7k per year, but stephens correct if renting £10k upwards all depending on your preferences,
Dahryn Kaewkul

post_text: Hi , we are considering to relocate to Phuket from Israel.  I would appreciate if you can share how's life in phuket for expats. Which area are popular for expats?

comments.comment: Cherntalay is the place to stay
Choeng Thale, Thalang, Kathu and Rawai are popular amongst expats.

It will also depend whether you have any specific hobbies like diving or perhaps golf, as these may influence your decision on location. We live in Cape Panwa, which is a very quiet area, which we like; others want more "night life". Would suggest you come for a holiday, rent a car, and drive around the island looking for an area that suits you and your wife lifestyle.

subcomments.subcomment: we both likes to dive and snorkel.
subsubcomments: Have a look around Chalong and surrounding areas.

comments.comment: It matters not, Phuket is tiny and you can be anywhere generally within 30 minutes unless you do all the way north to all the way south, so it really doesn't matter.

Life here is nice, if you don't work. About areas, you'll hear many opinions but the truth is that the decision is personal. You should rent a place for 1 month,and take your time to watch around and decide,according to what you need. If you have a dog,better a villa because not all Condos are Pet friendly.

I live in Chiang Mai and Phuket, going back and forth. In Phuket, you get the Thai life style  plus a nice marine surrounding plus a good infrastructure (for Thailand) plus a heavy Western influence due to tourism. The climate is great, because the tropical heat is attenuated by (almost) constant sea breezes. Food and entertainment are likewise great. Prices in Phuket are rather high compared to other areas of Thailand, especially real estate. It can get really crowded by tourists during the high season.

Hi, please can someone point me in the right direction of who can help me with advice? The hotel owner of one of the units I'm renting has told me they are in debt and will probably lose their apartments, the court hearing is coming up in September. I have 1 years lease. They tell me the new owners will not allow me to stay and I will have to move out or they will increase my rent! Where do I stand if I have a contract ? Will notice be given or I'll just be asked to leave with new owners? They won't give me details of the new owner either so I can't talk with them 🤦🏼‍♀️

comments.comment: You need to talk to an attorney, not a facebook group. Try https://www.siam-legal.com/.

subcomments.subcomment: thanks! Just wondered if anyone had a similar experience so it actually saves me going to a lawyers office
subsubcomments: Anonymous member So, Daniel commented below. Sounds reasonable. Is that the legal advice you were looking for?
yes certainly is.

comments.comment: Thai law requires the new owner to honor the current leases, unless agreed upon by BOTH parties. They can't legally raise the rent, kick you out, make you sign a new lease, etc. This is the law. But it's Thailand... So in reality,  be prepared for problems.Also, this sounds like they just want you out for high season and there's a good chance there are no new owners. They think they'll be able to get more for the unit daily than what you're paying, so would rather take their chances. Seen it so many times...

subcomments.subcomment: Thank you  your advice is really helpful

comments.comment: I’m sorry you are dealing with that. 2 things: 1-I have available rooms in my building in rawai. 2- I can talk to the owner can talk to to possibly buy from them before they lose it. If you know their name and number, please dm me

Phuket International Church Family

post_text: 30 year lease (land) question: what is the ramifications when the lessor sells the title or closes the business that owns the title. I’m assuming it passes but does that mean I have to chase a new lease contract with the owner or does it stand in the records of the land office?

comments.comment: Lessor sells the land and lease is registered then no effect on lease or lessee. Lessor becomes insolvent or struck off, lease remains registered but if you see a company trying to close when it is a lessor you need to object to the closure of the company on the grounds the company still has assets and liabilities. If there is a renewal clause then the sale of the land means the new lessor does not have to renew unless it enters into a specific contract with penalties for non performance.

If the title is owned by a company and the company closes this is a huge problem because the title essentially will have no owner. With no owner the title cannot be transferred or altered. As an agent we’ve been involved in this kind of thing before, usually because the company fails to provide an audit for three years  and is shut down by the business department. The only way to reopen the company is with a court order, a process which usually takes around one year. I am not sure it is possible to voluntarily close a company that has assets, and even it were I cannot imagine a reason why anyone would want to do this without first selling on the assets. If the title with the lease is sold this has no impact on your rights and the new owner is bound by the same terms as the previous. The lease is tied to the title and not the owner.

subcomments.subcomment: thanks Stephen. In your opinion if my plan is to simply use the land for a house for 30 years and walk away would I still have any issues? If so what issues?
subsubcomments: Chris Edwards with that in mind as long as the landlord has no right to terminate the lease early and the lease is noted on the back of the Chanote by the land department and you have a copy of that I can’t see any problems. I’m not a lawyer so suggest you take legal advice also. Happy to recommend a firm if you wish.As you want to build on this land make sure that this is permitted under the title, only NS4J Chanote) and NS3G really
much appreciated Stephen. Seeing a lawyer at ILO tomorrow.
Sam Fauma and his team can advise you well.

Hi Sean, I went through the same process, I couldn't find a bank that were prepared to take them. I bought a coin counting machine from lazada, counted it all up, 15 years of coins. I had over 25,000 baht in coins. I now use them every day. The place I stop to buy regular items like morning coffee etc, i just count out what I know I'll need and go spend it. I did receive some funny looks frome veryone around me, but now they are used to it, a daily event. They appreciate the change. Slowly denting my 25 k of coin!!!

Hello expats. I've just been approved by Pacific Cross for health insurance. I really know nothing about them. Rates seem reasonable. Does anyone have experience with this company, good or bad? Any advice? I was turned down by a couple other Thai companies due to minor preexisting conditions.

comments.comment: My wife has had Pacific Cross for a dozen years. She has a little higher annual deductible, because that is her choice. They pay according to the policy terms/deductible.She has been satisfied with their service.

subcomments.subcomment: Cool. It was a low-hassle application and quick approval. I like that part. Does your wife have a better company now?
subsubcomments: the plan my wife has is her choice in order to get the best coverage possible. She has a very good policy to best cover her needs.You can adjust the coverage each year.

comments.comment: Use an agent to deal with them…some things get complicated but cover is really good for the price I use Darren at https://www.seek2insure.com/Make sure you get outpatients cover and medicines as those bills can more expensive than treatments/surgery.

subcomments.subcomment: I totally disagree - why would you use an agent ?? And why would you get outpatient??
subsubcomments: I have full coverage which includes outpatient costs.  If you read up then outpatient costs can be substantial depending on the illness or injury which can require many outpatient visits.I used an agent to get quotes for exactly what I wanted and I can contact for help sorting out the issues that do and will occur.

Сообщение до тех кто устал гонять на бордеры и планирует делать визу. 
Студенческая виза - 49500 бат, это окончательная цена с тремя продлениями и пошлиной. Кто найдет дешевле (даст контакт школы , где подтвердят цену) - сделаю дешевле. 
Через эту контору себе делал студенческую, маме пенсионную. Работают на Пхукете больше 10 лет. Все четко и быстро. Делают все типы виз.
На острове с ноября, обучаю детей футболу, также организуем футбольные игры и турниры, многие меня знают из футбольного круга. Можно встретиться или созвониться, если вдруг кто особенно недоверчив. Пишите в личные сообщения. Всем хорошего настроения🙏🏻

comments.comment: No one sells "garden quality" soil here except in the small bags you see for sale along the side of the road (usually 4-6 bags for 100 baht) and they usually contain more coconut than soil. But if you want to see if a garden center can do what you're looking for, go talk to M Garden. Otherwise you can get trucks of normal fill dirt, then work the soil yourself. Local plants and trees grow fine in it as the plants are used to it. https://goo.gl/maps/vKJB6LVjwaDzEQfQ8

For inquiries,
